fields.description: We seem to have built up a nasty list of global variables, and rather than go through each plan and checking variables off, I thought it might be a good idea to have a "Usages" button next to each variable showing me what plans are using that variable. (ie, one of those question mark icons next to the delete icon)
fields.summary: Global variable usage

fields.description:
Linked repositories are cool, but in some plans (most notably our release plans), we want to do some repository magic (like using the jgitflow-maven-plugin) that requires a non-shallow full clone.

But I also don't want to have all the other build plans that can get away with a shallow clone to be pulling down the full repository, nor do I want to manage two linked repositories for each repository, each bringing their own repository cache overhead (although that is the work-around I'm using at the moment).

So, would it be possible to add more override options to the "Source Code Checkout" task?

I mainly (at this time) just want it possible to override the "Use shallow clones" and "Fetch whole repository" options. I realize that overriding these options might negate any repository cache benefit.
fields.summary: Override linked repository settings on checkout

fields.description: If you create a new Deployment project in Bamboo Cloud, then check the project permissions you'll see that by default the 'Anonymous' group has access to view those projects.
fields.summary: Deployment projects allow anonymous access by default

fields.description:
Suppose, there are two build plans A and B.
B is dependent on A (this dependency has been configured in the build plan A). So, A is parent and B is child.
Now the scenario is -
Build plan A is triggered - first
Build plan B is triggered manually when plan A is running - second
Now, both A and B are running.
Scenario, dependent build B(from build plan A) is not getting triggered after completion of manually triggered build B.
Ideally, dependent build B should wait in queue and should get triggered automatically after the completion of manually triggered build.
fields.summary: dependency blocking strategy should work independent of polling mechanism

fields.description:
Assume a simple setup: 2 Agents, 1 stage with 2 jobs:

Stage X
- Job A can run on Agent 1 and Agent 2
- Job B can run on Agent 2

What I want to see is that Job A is always run on Agent 1 so that Job B can run at the same time. 
But this is not the case: Job A is sometimes run on Agent 2 which causes Job B to be queued. If Bamboo would choose the agents better, they could run at the same time.
fields.summary: Optimize agent assignment

fields.description:
One of the problems with Bamboo that I've encountered (and seen a lot of other people wanting to fix/change/workaround) is that when I have a build plan set to automatically create branch plans, I don't want it to run on the main repository branch.

eg:
- I create a plan and as part of that I have to set a repository. I need to set a branch for this repository. This is the "main repository branch".
- I setup triggers for the plan because I don't want to manually set those triggers on each branch plan. eg repository polling.
- This causes the "main branch plan" to also be triggered when the conditions are met.

The most common "workaround" I have seen for this is "Just put up with it". But when you have several plans on the same repository, this can produce a lot of notification spam when a commit is made to the main branch. 

Also, it becomes possible for people to perform the incorrect actions when they access the "main branch" for a plan that has manual stages meant for a branch. (eg, a release branch build that allows you to finish the release. In this case I *could* run the release-finish on the main branch)

What you need to solve this, is a plan that has no "main branch" triggers, but does have triggers for the branch plans. I know triggers can be overridden on branch plans, but there is currently no way of doing this in conjunction with the automatic branch plan creation.

So what I'm asking for is an addition to the Branches tab of a build plan (or anywhere) where I can set triggers that will automatically be applied to a branch plan when it is created. (bonus points if you do this on manual OR automatic branch plan creation)

What do you think?
fields.summary: Allow automatic branch plans to override triggers

fields.description:
I'd like to see the ability to disable the "rebuild failed/incomplete jobs only" action in the plan's Run menu. This action destroys the history and artifacts of the failed job, and using it makes it hard to get a good grasp of the reliability of the builds. 

This can be partially addressed by educating team members not to use it, but a better solution would be to allow the action to be disabled, either server-side or on a per-plan basis.
fields.summary: Allow "rebuild failed jobs" action to be disabled

fields.description: Bamboo would be perfect for our team if had this one missing feature. The fact that we can only use auto plan branching from the Default repo ruins our workflow and prevents us from using Bamboo, unfortunately.
fields.summary: Automatic branching from multiple repos

fields.description: The option to create or link a JIRA Issue from a failed unit test (appears on the same menu which allows you to Quarantine a test) is only available to plan admins.  I understand that Quarantine is only available to admins, but I believe the option to create/link a JIRA issue should be available to everyone with the 'build' permission for the plan.  There is no way to create this link from the JIRA side that I have found.
fields.summary: Create JIRA Issue from failed test is only available to Plan Admins

fields.description: A good use case for this is explained in this answers post: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/309232/trigger-bamboo-build-upon-creation-and-update-of-stash-pull-request
fields.summary: Building Stash pull requests in Bamboo
Stop the log spam when the instance is locked

fields.description:
Currently, the sections under Build Service (All Builds, Specific Project, Specific Plan, Specific Build Result) are suggesting to use the {{expand}} parameter this way:
{noformat}
?expand=results.result.artifacts
?expand=results.result.labels
?expand=results.result.comments
?expand=results.result.jiraIssues
{noformat}
However, these things are not being expanded in the XML result. The correct values for the {{expand}} parameters should not contain {{results.result}}, but only {{artifacts}}, {{labels}}, {{comments}}, and {{jiraIssues}}.
fields.summary: Update Build Services in the REST API documentation

Add the ability to disable notification on a plan for users that have committed to the repository

fields.description: At the moment when taking artifact, there is not way to tell bamboo to get also the hidden files like he .git directory. Bamboo by default ignores them. It will be nice to have a flag for this feature
fields.summary: Add a flag to allow or disable the use of default exclude patterns (.git, .svn, etc.) when getting artifacts

fields.description: Scenario: "I want to be able to write a value to a custom field or a label for an issue that is included in a Bamboo build and deployed by Bamboo so one can then do a query in JIRA for a list of issues that are assigned to me, resolved, and DEPLOYED. I noticed if I open an issue that is built and deployed thru Bamboo, the Dev Panel of the issue indicates that the issue is deployed. However, I want to be able to query JIRA for issues that are deployed. Right now I can only tell if an issue in JIRA was deployed thru Bamboo by opening the issue in JIRA."
fields.summary: Ability to set a label for an issue to indicate it has been deployed

fields.description:
The UI to re-order Environements in the Configure Deployment Project page is cumbersome.  I currently have to repeat these steps to move an environment up or down the list.
1. Click Edit button on specific environment
2. Click Action drop down
3. Click Move Up/Down
4. Wait for page to refresh

I would much prefer to simple drag environments up and down the list until I have the order I want and click Save.
fields.summary: Configure Deployment Project Environment List ordering

fields.description:
We create new "linked repos" when doing a proof of concept for changes to revisioned deploy scripts to do demos before unleashing them on all deploy instances. When the merge to master is completed, we remove the branch and then remove the linked repo that references that branch. Unfortunately, when removing the linked repo, we get a "red box" error {panel:bgColor=#FF0000}An unexpected error has occurred
Not Found{panel}
The linked repos linger without a way to remove them.
On a hunch, I'll test a potential workaround by restoring the branch and trying to delete the linked repo referencing it.
fields.summary: Can't remove or delete a "linked repository"

fields.description: It will be nice to have the working directory viewable/browsable from the UI. This will be helpful for debugging purposes.
fields.summary: Make the build working directory browsable from the UI

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As a Bamboo user, I'd like to be able to filter the Bamboo wallboard with a labels parameter in the URL. E.g. http://bamboo.com/telemetry.action?filter=favourites&labels=frontend,backend

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement the functionality that supports a labels parameter in the filter for the wallboard.

h3. Workaround 
# Set a personal dashboard filter that includes labels at:
#* http://bamboo.com/ajax/configureFilter.action?returnUrl=%2FallPlans.action
# Now tell the wallboard to use your dashboard filter with the following:
#* http://bamboo.com/telemetry.action?filter=dashboard
fields.summary: Filter Bamboo wallboard with labels in the URL

fields.description:
h4. Steps to reproduce:

- Create a deployment project.
- Deploy it.
- Terminate the agent before the deployment is complete.
- The deployment will now be stuck with deploying status and can't be stopped.

h4. Expected behavior:

Deployment process should automatically detect an agent going offline and failing the job.
 
h4. Workaround:

Restart Bamboo to stop the deployment. For Bamboo OnDemand customers please raise a support ticket at support.atlassian.com to request for restart.
fields.summary: Deployment stuck and can not be stopped when the agent is terminated within the deployment process

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Other Atlassian products such as JIRA, Confluence and Bitbucket all offer a simple and easy to use {{.bin}} installer on Linux. This makes installs and upgrades easier.

h3. Suggested Solution
Create a {{.bin}} installer for Bamboo on Linux. Ideally this installer would have additional options to setup a dedicated bamboo system user and install a systemd service configuration. The installer should also have the ability to run in an unattended mode for automating installation.
fields.summary: Implement a .bin installer for Bamboo on Linux with unattended installation

fields.description:
Within a Plan's 'Tasks' tab, when I click the link to view its variables on Chrome and Safari, the pop-up that opens isn't rendered correctly.
Check screenshots for details.

Also from Bamboo Administration > System Errors, when there's errors, clicking the 'View Error Log' link produces the same behavior.

This is only happening on Bamboo Cloud (OnDemand) and on Google Chrome on Mac OS, Linux and Windows, and Safari on Mac OS and Windows. 
It works on Firefox (Chrome, Safari, and Firefox were all running latest versions).

I tested it on Bamboo Server version 5.6.2, and it worked on Chrome and Firefox.
fields.summary: Tasks' variables and Error Logs are not rendered on Google Chrome and Safari

fields.description:
When you create a plan that uses a Stash source repository, with Stash 3.1 and later, Bamboo will automatically use the '-repository triggers the build when changes are committed-' trigger option instead of using the 'polling the repository for changes' option. This reduces the load on the Bamboo and Stash servers because Bamboo doesn't need to send poll requests (for each branch of each plan) to the Stash server every 3 minutes (the default polling period). Instead, Stash will trigger Bamboo whenever there is a push to the repository.

Instead, Bamboo selects "{{Stash repository triggers the build when changes are committed}}" as default trigger type if the repository host is Stash and the versions as compatible with the above mentioned.
!bamboo.triggers.jpg|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Amend trigger default selection under Stash's documentation

fields.description:
When you create a plan that uses a Stash source repository, with Stash 3.1 and later, Bamboo will automatically use the 'repository triggers the build when changes are committed' trigger option instead of using the 'polling the repository for changes' option. This reduces the load on the Bamboo and Stash servers because Bamboo doesn't need to send poll requests (for each branch of each plan) to the Stash server every 3 minutes (the default polling period). Instead, Stash will trigger Bamboo whenever there is a push to the repository.

Trigger type: *Stash repository triggers the build when changes are committed*
!bamboo.triggers.jpg|thumbnail!
\\ 
Please, update the content of the following URLs to include this new feature:
* [Repository triggers the build when changes are committed|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Repository+triggers+the+build+when+changes+are+committed]
* [Bamboo - Triggering builds|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Triggering+builds]
fields.summary: Missing "Stash triggering feature" under Bamboo's documentation.

fields.description:
All Atlassian Labs plugins we have in Marketplace are currently marked as unsupported. 
Examples:
- [Bamboo JBoss Tasks|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jboss.bamboo-jboss-plugin]
- [FindBugs for Bamboo|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.findbugs]
- [PMD for Bamboo|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.bamboo.pmd_bamboo]
- [Checkstyle for Bamboo|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-checkstyle-plugin]
- [SBT Task for Bamboo|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.sbt.bamboo-sbt-plugin]

We receive support requests for these add-ons. Also, many customers are seeking documentation that are often missing. 
*This ticket is created to have a focused space for discussing the requests we receive for these plugins and whether we plan to provide support/documentation for any or all of them.*

fields.description:
SCP task in deployment project's environment throws NPE after the build plan moved to another project or get deleted.
{noformat}
java.lang.NullPointerException
at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.scp.ScpTaskConfigurator.addArtifactsFromDownloaderTasks(ScpTaskConfigurator.java:247)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.scp.ScpTaskConfigurator.addArtifactData(ScpTaskConfigurator.java:218)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.scp.ScpTaskConfigurator.populateContextForEdit(ScpTaskConfigurator.java:187)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.admin.config.task.TaskUIConfigBean.prepareEditHtml(TaskUIConfigBean.java:124)
{noformat}

h3. Cause
This is due to the new plan is having different artifact(different ID). *Artifact Download* task is still pointing to old artifact from previous plan thus the SCP task can't find the artifact.

It seems that *Artifact Download* task failed to get updated with a new set of artifacts from the new plan.

h3. Workaround
Edit the environment's task. Delete the current *Artifact Download* task as well as the *SCP task* and recreate them accordingly.
fields.summary: SCP task throws NPE after the build plan moved to another project or deleted
MSTest runner task should allow entering additional options

fields.description:
A customer comment:

On Windows 2012 Server (bamboo 5.4.2), the "bin\service.bat install" command creates a service called "Atlassian Bamboo".
However, the "InstallAsService.bat" script creates a service called "Apache Tomcat Bamboo"

It would be better if these names were the same, yes?

See https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Running+Bamboo+as+a+Windows+service+as+the+local+user?focusedCommentId=471793692#comment-471793692
fields.summary: On Windows, the Bamboo service has different names depending on the script used

fields.description:
[Subgit|http://subgit.com/index.html] creates writable Git mirror of a local or remote Subversion repository and use both Subversion and Git interchangeably. It will be nice to have our git plugin recognise and handle such repositories. We have an [svn mirror|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/org.tmatesoft.subgit.stash-svn-importer] that allows users migrate their SVN repo to stash. This repos can be cloned in to Bamboo with some attendant errors like:

fields.description:
After creating a deployment project with an environment, I find I usually need to recreate the whole environment with tasks multiple times (live, staging, QA, UAT, etc)

I do not currently see any way to do this, other than manually creating a new environment and then recreating all the tasks, which is a PITA.
fields.summary: Clone deployment project environments

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo Cloud (OnDemand) instances are privisioned with the 'Atlassian Bamboo Stash Repository Plugin' *disabled*. Please have this plugin enabled so users can link to a Stash repository using the 'Administration' menu from Bamboo.

According to the documentation, this should be possible. Currently users are unable to select 'Stash' from the *Repository host* field when trying to link a Stash repo with Bamboo. There's a request to have the documentation edited, here: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-15177.

*Workaround*

Users should still be able to connect to a Stash repo from Bamboo OnDemand, but not this way. Instead, users should go to the clone tab from their Stash repo, get the http or https clone address, go back to Bamboo and add a repo (e.g. type: Git) using that address. When adding a repo, under the Advanced options, there's a "Web repository" option, from there users can select *Stash*. It will checkout from stash the same as it would from any other repo, but won't have the same features provided by the plugin.
fields.summary: Enable 'Atlassian Bamboo Stash Repository Plugin' by default

fields.description:
{panel}
(i) *The procedure below requires direct changes into the database being used by Bamboo. Because of that, do not proceed without [exporting your Bamboo data first|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/exporting-data-for-backup-289277255.html]. Own a valid database backup before proceeding.*
{panel}
h3. Summary

Bamboo Server fails to start up due to a corruption on the {{LIST_POSITION}} column of {{CHAIN_STAGE}} table. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
At this stage, the steps to reproduce this are not clear. It is known that this could be caused by editing a Build Plan (i.e. re-ordering the steps in a build plan) and restarting the instance, for example.

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo shouldn't get into this database corruption state.

h3. Actual Results
Due to the corruption, the below exceptions are thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{code}
2011-10-12 11:16:16,966 FATAL [main] [BambooContainer] Cannot start bamboo
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: -1

h3.Workaround

*Identifying the problem:*
You should run the following query in order to find out the duplicates:
{noformat}
select stage.*
  from chain_stage as stage
  join build as chain ON stage.build_id = chain.build_id
 where chain.full_key = 'PLAN-KEY-0'
 order by stage.list_position
{noformat}

As an example, let's look at a _bad_ result for the query above:
||STAGE_ID||NAME||BUILD_ID||LIST_POSITION||
|8389098|Stage 2|4063315|	1|
|8389099|Stage 2|4063368|	1|
|8389100|Stage 2|8422478|	1|
|8389101|Stage 3|4063315|	1|
|8389102|Stage 3|4063368|	1|
|8389103|Stage 3|8422478|	1|

From this result, you can see that the 3 {{BUILD_ID}}: {{4063315}}, {{4063368}} and {{8422478}} are duplicated as they appear _twice_ on the table above.

That means that each one of those {{BUILD_ID}} need to be fixed on the {{CHAIN_STAGE}} table.

If this query had returned zero results, the corruption we are trying to fix wouldn't exist.

*How to fix the problem:*
If you run the following query specifying one of the duplicate {{BUILD_ID}}'s reported above:
{noformat}
SELECT * FROM CHAIN_STAGE WHERE BUILD_ID=8422478 ORDER BY BUILD_ID, LIST_POSITION;
{noformat}

You will get the following result which evidences the corruption on the {{CHAIN_STAGE}} table:
||STAGE_ID||CREATED_DATE||UPDATED_DATE||NAME||DESCRIPTION||OPTIONAL_STAGE||MARKED_FOR_DELETION||BUILD_ID||LIST_POSITION||
|8389103	|(null)|	(null)	|Stage 3	| |false	|false	|8422478|	1|
|8389100	|2015-10-24 13:00:38	|2015-10-24 13:00:38|	Stage 2|	|	false	|true	|8422478|1|
|8389106	|(null)	|(null)	|Stage 4|		|false	|false	|8422478	|2|

Therefore, in order to identify what needs to be fixed, 3 separate queries would have to be run against the db so you can see the corruption for each {{BUILD_ID}}.  In this specific example, they are:
{noformat}
SELECT * FROM CHAIN_STAGE WHERE BUILD_ID=4063315 ORDER BY BUILD_ID, LIST_POSITION;
SELECT * FROM CHAIN_STAGE WHERE BUILD_ID=4063368 ORDER BY BUILD_ID, LIST_POSITION;
SELECT * FROM CHAIN_STAGE WHERE BUILD_ID=8422478 ORDER BY BUILD_ID, LIST_POSITION;
{noformat}
*But wait... Where is the corruption on the table above?*
Notice from the result above that for each row of {{CHAIN_STAGE}} the {{LIST_POSITION}} for the {{BUILD_ID=8422478}} holds the values {{1}}, {{1}} and {{2}} when it should be holding the values {{0}}, {{1}} and {{2}}. The values should _always_ start off from {{0}}, otherwise Bamboo won't start. 

That's what the corruption is about.

*How to fix it?*
In order to fix this, you will need to analyse the corruption for each one of the queries above and manually fix the problematic rows.

- *If you're running Bamboo with an external db ...*
Then just update the rows manually. As mentioned before, the result should have been {{0}}, {{1}} and {{2}} and *not* {{1}}, {{1}} and {{2}}.
So, in order to fix the problem in this specific corrupt output, you would need to update the first row _only_ by running the following query:
{noformat}
UPDATE CHAIN_STAGE SET LIST_POSITION = 0 WHERE STAGE_ID = '8389103'
{noformat}
In our example, after analysing the output of the {{SELECT * FROM CHAIN_STAGE WHERE BUILD_ID=... ORDER BY BUILD_ID, LIST_POSITION;}}, the final set of queries to fix this is:
{noformat}
UPDATE CHAIN_STAGE SET LIST_POSITION = 0 WHERE STAGE_ID = '8389103'
UPDATE CHAIN_STAGE SET LIST_POSITION = 0 WHERE STAGE_ID = '8389101'
UPDATE CHAIN_STAGE SET LIST_POSITION = 0 WHERE STAGE_ID = '8389102'
{noformat}


- *If you're running Bamboo with an HSQLDB ...*
HSQLDB is the in-memory database _for evaluation purposes only_. If you're using this in production, well, you should really have [migrated to an external database by now|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/connecting-bamboo-to-an-external-database-289276815.html] because we don't recommend production environments to be using HSQLDB.
-- *How to detect issue and fix it:*
If you're in this scenario, though, here is how you can fix it:
--- Stop your Bamboo instance process.
--- In order to run the queries to identify the corruption, you will need to [Connect to your HSQLDB using DBVisualizer|https://confluence.atlassian.com/conf51/connecting-to-hsqldb-using-dbvisualizer-336169749.html] and run the {{SELECT}} queries as described under the *Identifying the problem* section.
---- If your database is big (consider big ~200MB), you might consider [increasing the memory allocated for your DBVisualizer to 2048m|http://confluence.dbvis.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=3146118]
--- Make sure Bamboo is not running. This is very important, otherwise the values we update on the next step will be overwritten and void the fix.
--- Edit the {{<BAMBOO_HOME>/database/defaultdb.script}}. In there, you will find queries that populate the HSQLDB when Bamboo is started up. For the example we fixed here, you would have found:
{noformat}
INSERT INTO CHAIN_STAGE VALUES(8389101,NULL,NULL,'Stage 3','',FALSE,FALSE,4063315,1)
INSERT INTO CHAIN_STAGE VALUES(8389102,NULL,NULL,'Stage 3','',FALSE,FALSE,4063368,1)
INSERT INTO CHAIN_STAGE VALUES(8389103,NULL,NULL,'Stage 3','',FALSE,FALSE,8422478,1)
{noformat}
--- You'd have to change that the {{INSERT}} queries above into the ones below so that they can start off at {{0}}:
{noformat}
INSERT INTO CHAIN_STAGE VALUES(8389101,NULL,NULL,'Stage 3','',FALSE,FALSE,4063315,0)
INSERT INTO CHAIN_STAGE VALUES(8389102,NULL,NULL,'Stage 3','',FALSE,FALSE,4063368,0)
INSERT INTO CHAIN_STAGE VALUES(8389103,NULL,NULL,'Stage 3','',FALSE,FALSE,8422478,0)
{noformat}
fields.summary: LIST_POSITION column of CHAIN_STAGE table gets corrupted causing Bamboo startup to fail

fields.description:
It would very helpful to display the maven modules in the Build Summary tab of a Bamboo build (for Maven 2.x/3.x jobs).

As a first pass, just show the summary as in the end of the log.  Perhaps link each module title to the line number in the log file somehow, so you can jump right there.  You could keep going, and breakdown the maven mojo's that ran successfully/failed as well, again with links to the line numbers in the logs.  And I'm sure more could be done...

Don't let a full feature set block an incrementally added feature though -- anything in this direction would be helpful.

As an added bonus, make Maven's {{--fail-at-end}} option be a first class checkbox on the Job configuration, but its simple enough to do this manually anyhow.
fields.summary: Show Maven Modules on Build Summary

fields.description:
This bug occurs for Plans that were themselves created from a Plan Template and also for Plans that were cloned from a Plan created from a Plan Template.

h4. Steps to Reproduce:
* Create a plan with Plan Templates - call this plan "My Plan".
* Clone "My Plan" and name it "My Plan - clon"
* Configure Plan > Plan Details.
* Change the Plan Name from "My Plan - clon" to "My Plan - clone"
* Hit save.

h4. Outcome:
Save fails with an error message:
*This project name already exists.*

bq. Atlassian Bamboo version 5.7-m2 build 5704 - 10 Sep 14 (DevMode Enabled)
fields.summary: Cannot edit plan name for clones of Plan Templates.

fields.description:
I have a couple of suggestions to improve Build/Job Results page -

1. Please remove the RED/GREEN bar at the top of the Build/Job Results page, instead you could color code the Build # (under Project/Plan title) to indicate Success/Failure, you can even add a little status icon next to it. Not only this would make the page look easy on the eyes, but it would create more screen space to view the logs and other essential information. Engineers don't need to see a big RED/GREEN bar to figure out whether a build succeeded or failed. 

2. Please change the default behavior of Build/Job Results page to open with the left side bar (i.e. Navigation Bar) expanded. Engineers are more interested in Job Results rather than overall Build Results especially when a Build is failing. This would reduce the number of clicks/scrolls  for them to get to full logs for failing jobs. 

ps: I come from Jenkins world and I am a minimalist. So far I like Bamboo, except for some excessive/unnecessary design flaws. 

Thanks
fields.summary: Build/Job Results User Interface
Changing the 'Create' button on Bamboo to a 'Quick Run' function

fields.description:
The change added in BAM-11824 is now causing our builds to fail due to the environment being larger than 32kb.
The error in our situation comes from building an installer using Wix (see http://stackoverflow.com/a/9722623/995058)

I can see that this would be a useful feature for a lot of people, however I would propose that it is a configurable option so that it can be disabled by those who don't need it.
fields.summary: Build fails due to unnecessarily large process space

fields.description:
Summary:
A build is run and all of the jobs in the first stage appear in the "pending" state. When pending job details are shown, Bamboo gives the following status:
{{Job has not yet been queued. Waiting for prior stages to complete}}

In every case, the agent matrix shows that suitable agents are available for the jobs.

On one of the servers, IBAC, the build queue was completely empty - there was 0 activity on the instance, yet the 'stuck' build wouldn't start.

We've had this happen 4 times in less than 24 hours on 2 different production Bamboo instances ([IBAC|https://intsys-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/] and [JBAC|https://jira-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/]). More information is available on [BUILDENG-6431|https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/browse/BUILDENG-6431]

No log output was produced that mentioned the stuck job keys. DEBUG-level logging has been enabled on IBAC in case it happens again.
fields.summary: Jobs failing to queue on production Bamboo instances (5.7-m2)

fields.description:
For us a major feature (argument to switch to Bamboo) is to be able to build only pull-requests.

Our workflow requires successful builds before merging pull-requests.
Because we have long running builds (40min) we need to prefer builds triggered by pull-reqest create/update over user-builds (triggered by push to branches without an active pull-request). Right now, we even want to disable all non-pull-request builds, to get the pull-requests merged as quick as possible.

Two Bamboo Plan Triggers would do it:
- "Stash repository triggers the build when pull-requests are created or updated"
- "Stash repository triggers the build when changes are commited to branches without an active pull-request"
fields.summary: Trigger to Build only for pull-requests

fields.description:
Bamboo has a new triggering feature "*Stash repository triggers the build when changes are committed*" that has been implemented to Stash 3.1+. Unfortunately, those who have Stash -3.1 will not have this feature and they are not notified by Bamboo about this incompatibility either.

The proposed idea would be a *notification* saying the feature requires Stash 3.1+ installed, running and an application link configured in order to work.
fields.summary: Inter-applications incompatibility notification automatically detected

fields.description: I would like to be able to create a generic plan for cloning that will include the jUnitParser.  Currently the parser will fail the builds if no tests are found.  I would like to be able to influence this behavior and instead just have it parse tests if they exist.
fields.summary: Allow JUnitParser to be configured to not fail builds if not tests are found

fields.description:
Having a repository Git in Stash, Bitbucket or any other location and adds it to Bamboo under "{{Bamboo administration >> Build resources >> Linked repositories}}" or under "{{Plan configuration >> Repositories}}" tab does not enables Bamboo to push back to a repository.

Once you create a "{{Source Code Checkout}}" task and run your build, Bamboo will checkout from your repository under the "{{<bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/<project-plan-key>}}" directory by default.

h6. Bamboo Server
In Bamboo Server, running the following command under the directory "{{<bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/<project-plan-key>/.git}}" you will:
{code}
# command:
git config -l

# response (sample)
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	user.name=<USER NAME>
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	user.email=<USER EMAIL>
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	core.editor=<EDITOR>
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	core.excludesfile=/Users/<USER>/.gitignore_global
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	difftool.sourcetree.cmd=opendiff "$LOCAL" "$REMOTE"
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	difftool.sourcetree.path=
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	mergetool.sourcetree.cmd=/Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/opendiff-w.sh "$LOCAL" "$REMOTE" -ancestor "$BASE" -merge "$MERGED"
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	mergetool.sourcetree.trustexitcode=true
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	core.repositoryformatversion=0
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	core.filemode=true
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	core.bare=false
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	core.logallrefupdates=true
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	core.ignorecase=true
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	core.precomposeunicode=true
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	remote.origin.url=file:///<BAMBOO_HOME>/xml-data/build-dir/_git-repositories-cache/93be3...
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	remote.origin.fetch=+refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	branch.master.remote=origin
11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	branch.master.merge=refs/heads/master
{code}

Please, notice the entry (11-Sep-2014 10:41:03	remote.origin.url) is pointing to a cache file that Bamboo creates once a repository is linked.

By going to "{{Bamboo administration >> Build resources >> Repository settings}}" you will find all cached repositories Git under the "{{Git}}" section.

h6. Bamboo Cloud
In Bamboo Cloud, it is more likely the "{{remote.origin.url}}" will be pointing to "{{file://nothing}}" as per following:
{code}
11-Sep-2014 10:43:12	remote.origin.url=file://nothing
{code}

In either *Bamboo Server* or *Bamboo Cloud* by running the following command in a *Script* task you will find something like:
{code}
# command
git remote -v

# response (sample)
11-Sep-2014 10:45:32	origin        file:///<BAMBOO_HOME>/xml-data/build-dir/_git-repositories-cache/93be3c87266225a94f8f1c1929ecb2b0e85c989a (fetch)
11-Sep-2014 10:45:32	origin        file:///<BAMBOO_HOME>/xml-data/build-dir/_git-repositories-cache/93be3c87266225a94f8f1c1929ecb2b0e85c989a (push)
{code}

Depending on the Git repository you are working with, you would be able to push back to your repository by updating the *remote.origin.url* to point to your repository instead to a cache file.

In order to do it so, you can create a "{{Script}}" task in your Bamboo plan and add the following:
{code}
git remote remove origin
git remote add origin ssh://git@<stash-baseURL>:7999/<project-key>/<repository>.git
...
{code}

Instead of having to ask clients to update the remote origin to be "able to push back to a Git repository" it would be beneficial to have an option where you could choose if:
# you want to work with a cache file or;
# you want to preserve origin
fields.summary: Push back to Git repository - Preserve origin in repositories

fields.description:
When creating a new branch in Git, the first build of that branch does not list the commits and associated JIRA issues. If more than one commits were made, none of the commits are listed. 

Once you have created the first build, additional commits will be listed in new builds as expected. The commits of the first build aren't mentioned in the new build (which is good, since they are not new to that build).
fields.summary: First build of new branch does not include commits

fields.description:
With the release of Bamboo 5.6, the creation of AppLinks between Bamboo and Stash became very simple. From the Bamboo side, once the Stash URL is provided, the Admin can accept all the defaults of the wizard.

5.6 Support OAuth and will do all the setup work for you automatically.

*What needs to be changed*
*Page:* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+Stash
At the moment, it says that Basic is necessary. That was untill 5.5. We need a new section clarifying that in 5.6 and newer versions, creating an applink with all the options set to the default is enough.
Example:
{quote}
h3. To see Bamboo build results in Stash
1. Set up an application link from Bamboo to Stash:
*For Bamboo 5.6 and later versions:*
Just follow the instructions from Linking to Another Application and accept all the defaults proposed. Bamboo will create an application link using OAuth and with 2-Legged OAuth enabled, the configurations that Stash is expecting.
*For Bamboo 5.5 and previous versions:*
Ensure that the application link will use Basic Access for outgoing authentication. See: 
    a. Linking to Another Application
    b. Configuring Basic HTTP Authentication for an Application Link
{quote}

*Page:* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Linking+to+Another+Application
This page mentions:
{quote}
4. Use the wizard to finish configuring the link. If the application you are linking to does not have the Application Links plugin, you must supply additional information so the link can be set up. This information is required to set up a link with OAuth authentication.
{quote}
This is not true for 5.6 and newer versions. Bamboo detects what is the auth typo necessary in the other app and create the applink with the correct settings automatically.
fields.summary: Update Bamboo-Stash integration Docs to reflect the new AppLinks behavior

fields.description:
h6. Scenario
There are 6 build plans (*BP1*, *BP2*, *BP3*, *BP4*, *BP5* and *BP6*) and they work on a tree structure respecting the following:
# *BP4*, *BP5* and *BP6* are the *input*
# *BP1* is the *output*
# *BP2* cannot be triggered unless *BP4*, *BP5* and *BP6* have built successfully and generated their artifatcs, as *BP2* will consume the artifatcs generated by *BP4*, *BP5* and *BP6*.
# *BP3* cannot be triggered unless *BP4*, *BP5* and *BP6* have built successfully and generated their artifatcs, as *BP3* will consume the artifatcs generated by *BP4*, *BP5* and *BP6*.
# *BP1* cannot be triggered unless *BP2* and *BP3* have built successfully and generated their artifatcs, as *BP1* will consume the artifatcs generated by *BP2* and *BP3*.
# Once *BP4* gets in the queue, its siblings (*BP5* and *BP6*) should be queued as well.
# Once *BP5* gets in the queue, its siblings (*BP4* and *BP6*) should be queued as well.
# Once *BP6* gets in the queue, its siblings (*BP4* and *BP5*) should be queued as well.
fields.summary: Dependencies should have the option to parent as well

fields.description:
Bamboo plans can be triggered by other plans, and in doing so the child plan will assume that it should use the @head value from the parent plan repository.  Subsequent triggering of the "child" plan, not by the parent but by an update to a repository,  will not detect the latest @head, but use the parents last value which may be out of date.  Some customer workflows may require both parent/child relationships, and also arbitrary running of a child plan as well.

To improve this behaviour, if triggered by a parent plan, use the parents @head, but if a child plan is triggered by another method, enable a choice to find the @head as set in the current repo state, not the parents last.
fields.summary: Allow triggering a child plan to override parents git head

fields.description:
Discovered for Stash version 3.1.4

How to reproduce:
- create applink Stash - Bamboo
- add an SSH key without label (use example pasted below)
- verify that there is a key with *null* label (*not* an empty string - in such case everything will work) by GET-ing /rest/ssh/1.0/keys
- try adding a linked repository of Stash type in Bamboo

{code}
2014-09-05 09:33:01,628 DEBUG [http-apr-8085-exec-7] [StashRepository] Exception while negotiating key 
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.stash.rest.client.core.parser.UserSshKeyParser.apply(UserSshKeyParser.java:14)
	at com.atlassian.stash.rest.client.core.parser.UserSshKeyParser.apply(UserSshKeyParser.java:8)
	at com.google.common.collect.Iterators$8.next(Iterators.java:812)
	at com.google.common.collect.Lists.newArrayList(Lists.java:139)
	at com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList.copyOf(ImmutableList.java:256)
	at com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList.copyOf(ImmutableList.java:217)
	at com.atlassian.stash.rest.client.core.parser.ListParser.apply(ListParser.java:23)
	at com.atlassian.stash.rest.client.core.parser.ListParser.apply(ListParser.java:11)
	at com.atlassian.stash.rest.client.core.parser.PageParser.apply(PageParser.java:22)
	at com.atlassian.stash.rest.client.core.parser.PageParser.apply(PageParser.java:12)
	at com.atlassian.stash.rest.client.core.StashClientImpl.getCurrentUserKeys(StashClientImpl.java:215)
	at com.atlassian.stash.rest.client.core.StashClientImpl.isUserKey(StashClientImpl.java:226)
{code}

Key that caused the error: AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAAAABJQAAAIEA2YTE7vL0AFcCJe1fH+URNpU3R0Vtw5HP4OmR8IUAEyWoi4euYF3DNTKLUrJgD8UXkVtE7Lld+Kfkff+uu2ZBuaTHWEOqdF4xESdFzSHXxxkhPAl/LfUMXCrRG5UxPja+N3VTDL/ghAWqRSlja3cg56Ia5EkDH5LZpL4PYd7bo2c=

*Workaround:*
This issue is related to one of the SSH keys in Stash. There is one key without a label that causes the error. Please try to delete it (and maybe update with a new one, but this time with a label) and then try to add a Stash repository.
To do so, please go to Stash, then under your profile go to "Manage Account", then to "SSH Keys" and delete the single label-less key.
fields.summary: Can't create Stash repository in Bamboo when there is a Stash SSH key with 'null' label

fields.description:
I am trying to make a multi stage bamboo plan. 

First Stage - builds and deploys basic product code to a DEV env that is vanilla product - the deploy to DEV is a test in itself - to test if it can deploy successfully. 

Second Stage - adds dummy client customization code to the build and builds a WAR file with client code in it and deploys to a staging environment 

Third Stage - starts 6 separate cycles of automated tests in 6 different agents

Fourth Stage (is manual) - if all 6 test cycles passed, we release the build for consumption. 

I cannot make all of this work in a single plan - as two main features are missing in Bamboo 

Feature no.1: I have 2 separate deployment projects - one for the vanilla product deploy and two is for the client + product full deploy - both happen to two different environment and both need to be triggered after success of specific JOBs and not after success of the entire build plan .. 

Feature no.2: I want to trigger the build in Stage 2 - only after the vanilla product deployment to DEV for Stage 1 is successful. If DEV  deployment failed, there would be no point going through the rest of the stages.

Pls let me know if you need further information
fields.summary: Trigger subsequent builds from deployment projects and Link deployment projects to specific JOBs

fields.description:
When using the "Create New Issue" function, only the system fields are provided in the form. There are situations where the field configuration used in JIRA has some fields/customfields which are required and because these fields are not filled in the form, issue creation will fail with a warning. 
Here are basic system fields:
System fields:
Component
Fix Versions
Affect Versions
Priority
Due date
Environment
Assignee
Reporter
fields.summary: The form provided when creating new issue from Bamboo should provide a form that contains basic fields required for the particular project chosen

fields.description:
When adding a new Stash repository to a plan, customers are able to search for a repository. 

Stash refers to theses by using a naming convention of "StashProject / repository".  Many customers expect to be able to search for just the "StashProject" portion and have the associated repositories listed in the suggested options. 

However, the search will only resolve again the "repository" portion of the name.

Have Bamboo be able to search against a Stash project name as well as a repository.
fields.summary: Stash repository search won't match on project names

fields.description:
When an user administers a plan, they can assign additional permissions to other users. However it is not always clear based on user names who is already an admin user. When attempting to assign a user that already has admin permissions to the plan the operation will appear to silently fail. 

To improve this situation, provide feedback that the selected user already has admin privileges, and as such should be able to access the plan anyway, rather than simply failing with no feedback.

fields.description:
On the Branch Summary page for a plan, there is a Branch Statistics section which shows a chart of the duration of recent builds, as well as the average duration. In the case where a build is queued, the time it is queued is included in the duration.

There are two key problems here. First, this is giving an inaccurate picture of whether the build time has changed significantly with a commit - in other words, I can't see if a commit significantly increased the build time. Secondly, it can throw off the average build time, which means the progress bar for running builds will be wrong.

In my case I've had builds queued when there was no elastic agent (because it died or because we shut it down) and the duration is then thrown way off. I've had average duration jump from 6 min to 13 min on a single build. I attached a screenshot.

The build duration should include only time spent actually building, not the time queued. Ideally the queued time would be reported separately, as requested in BAM-10938; however, that is a separate issue.
fields.summary: When a build is queued the wrong duration is reported

fields.description:
When creating dependencies for plans which are dependent on multiple parent plans, you currently have to open each of the parent plans and define the child on the dependencies tab.

Once the dependencies are defined, you can view the parents from the child (from the dependencies tab, expand the Advanced section and they are listed as "Parent Plans")

It would be much easier to be able to define the parent plans from the child, from the one screen, rather than having to open multiple parents.
fields.summary: Allow dependences to be defined in the child plan as well as the parent

fields.description:
The JUnit Parser does not provide any information regarding Skipped tests. For example, the following is valid JUnit XML:

{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<testsuite errors="0" failures="0" skipped="1" tests="2" time="0.0090">
    <testcase classname="net.cars.engine.ValveTest" name="checkSpeed" time="0.0080" />
    <testcase classname="net.cars.engine.ValveTest" name="moveDown" time="0.0010">
        <skipped />
    </testcase>
</testsuite>
{code}

However, when parsed by the JUnit Parser, the above file will result in a build status with 1 test in total. There is no indication anywhere that a test has been skipped.

I believe this issue is related to:
* BAM-8983
* BAM-12340
* BAM-13060
fields.summary: JUnit Parser does not show Skipped tests

fields.description:
We have a Subversion repository containing several hundred software projects. I have configured a build plan in Bamboo for each software project from subversion.

The repository URL is in the format http://server.example.com/subversion/projectName/trunk.

I wanted to create a single linked repository that can be used by all the plans. I didn't see the Plan Name listed a variable in the documentation, so I created a variable in each plan named "svn_project" that could be used in the Repository URL string (http://server.example.com:81/subversion/${bamboo.svn_project}/trunk)

It would make cloning plans easier if the plan name were available as a variable instead of having to delete and create a new svn_project variable each time. If you forget to change the variable, it's not obvious until you come to deploy.
fields.summary: Make variable containing plan name available to Repository URL

fields.description:
This bug is related to BAM-1015, and all those in the wake of that.
BAM-1015 is resolved by introducing "multiple repositories per build-plan".

This is about allowing for multiple modules being listed for a single CVS repository link.

CVSs checkout support multiple modules being space-delimited on the command line.

When I try to do the same on Bamboo v6.3#6328, it "fakes it" and claims everything is a succes, but it doesn't checkout anything.

Log entry:
{quote}
command	01-Sep-2014 10:45:12	Running CVS command: 'checkout -P -N -kb -r rel-2-16-patches -D 2014-09-01 10:43:51 +0200 iform invoice jump signserver signservercore '\n             ... in: '/var/atlassian/application-data/bamboo/xml-data/build-dir/CVS-R216-JOB1'\n        ... CVSROOT: ':pserver:rlf@cvs.logiva.dk:2401/export/cvs-repository'
simple	01-Sep-2014 10:45:13	Updated source code to revision: 2014-09-01 10:43:51 +0200
simple	01-Sep-2014 10:45:13	Finished task 'CVS' with result: Success
{quote}
If I execute the same command from the shell, I get the desired checkout, provided I quote the -D argument.

I.e. 
{quote}
cvs checkout -P -N -kb -r rel-2-16-patches -D "2014-09-01 10:43:51 +0200" iform invoice jump signserver signservercore
{quote}

The only way to work around this (AFAIK), is to create a repository for each CVS module.

Needless to say, having multiple release branches suddenly becomes quite a hazzle - and maintaining all those repos becomes quite error-prone and tedious.

So, please allow the CVS integration to accept multiple modules per repository.
fields.summary: Support multiple modules for CVS repositories

fields.summary: JDK 1.8 support in Bamboo On Demand (Java 8)

fields.description:
We are a perl shop that uses Devel::Cover to report results about our test coverage. In order to play nice with Bamboo we are utilizing Devel::Cover::Report::Clover. However just the clover.xml that is generated with this plugin is not enough to satisfy our needs..

As such we generate an html file, with the conventional cover -report html_basic. We are then able to load the file into Bamboo's UI under the Clover Tab by telling Bamboo about the html that is produced by this report format.

However our framework produces a html page, that if viewed in the Bamboo UI, the clover tab, will cut off the majority of our results. Basically our framework has so many files that when Devel::Cover::Report::html_basic formats the page in top down format, most of the things are below the page fold. 

Can we please either allow this to detect if it needs a scroll bar, or some how load the entire page into the view portal
fields.summary: Allow for the clover tab to scroll if needed.

fields.description:
It looks like all results from the build results reports page, when generating reports across multiple plans, are only for the master branches. There should be a way to report for other branches inside the build plan.

Currently the only way to get an overall report for non-master branches is to access them individually and look at the *'Branch statistics'* section located at the right side of the screen:

!branch_statistics.png!

This is affecting Bamboo 5.6-OD-01.
fields.summary: Build results reports only show values for the master branch

fields.description: It's currently not possible to make a back up copy of a plan/stage without accessing the DB directly (BUILDDEFINITION table).
fields.summary: Provide functionality to make a back up of a plan/stage

fields.description:
As a user I would like to create dependencies on deployment plans.

Example:
Component A has a dependency on Component B.

Component A has its own Stash repository.
Component B has its own Stash repository.

The deployment plan for Component A should know if Component B is already successfully deployed, before deploying Component A.
fields.summary: Deployment Plan Dependencies
